# Packages

## Download data:

::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}
<a href="https://galah.ala.org.au">
![](images/hex/galah_logo.png){style="padding-right:15px; padding-left:15px;"} </a>
:::


::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### galah

{galah} is an R and Python interface to biodiversity data hosted by the
Atlas of Living Australia (ALA). It enables users to locate and download
species occurrence records (observations, specimens, eDNA records,
etc.), taxonomic information, or associated media such as images or
sounds, and to restrict their queries to particular taxa or
locations.<br> <br>
:::
:::


::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}

</a href="https://here.r-lib.org/index.html">

![](images/hex/herepkg.png){style="padding-right:15px; padding-left:15px;"}
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### here

{here} is a package that simplifies file referencing and importing and exporting files. Base systems can be complex, fragile and dependent on the way you organise your files. It allows intuitive means of directing to a file within the R interface in order for you to import pre-downloaded data into your system. It is also useful generally for data cleaning purposes. (artwork by [allison_horst](https://x.com/allison_horst?lang=en)) 
:::
:::




## Visualise your data:

::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}
</a href="https://github.com/ropensci/skimr">
![](images/hex/skimr_logo.png){style="padding-right:15px; padding-left:15px;"}
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### skimr

A helpful tool to quickly summarise your data, particularly prior to
data cleaning or whilst in the process of choosing an analysis. You can
also use the `skim` function to calculate the number of columns or rows,
view the number of empty or N/A data cells, and describe constituent
data types. The `summary` function provides summary statistics of
numerical data such as means, medians, minimum and maximums, as well as
quartiles. `skim` allows the user to have a basic grasp of the spread of
numercial data through averages, standard deviations and mini
histograms.
:::
:::

::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}
</a href="https://www.tidyverse.org">
![](images/hex/tidyverse_logo.png){style="padding-right:15px; padding-left:15px;"}
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### tidyverse

{tidyverse} is an umbrella package installing many packages into R that
are useful for data wrangling, cleaning and analysis. Some notable
packages within the tidyverse are {dplyr}, {ggplot2} and {stringr}. For
example, you can use {dplyr} to add new columns to your data, filter
your data for certain values and arrange rows in a preferred order;
{ggplot2} can plot and visualise your data, and {stringr} can (though
not limited to) help you locate and fix typos and extra spaces in your
data.
:::
:::

::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}

</a href="https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ozmaps/index.html">

![](images/hex/ozmaps_plot.png){style="padding-right:15px; padding-left:15px;"}
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### ozmaps

{ozmaps} is a package that hosts a collection of Australian mapping spatial object data: coastlines, state outlines, local government areas and electoral boundaries. It streamlines the process of visualising biodiversity data in the context of Australia without needing to externally download shapefiles, for example. Data for ozmaps is derived from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (2016). 

:::
:::

::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}
</a href="https://r-spatial.github.io/sf/">
![](images/hex/sf_hex.png){style="padding-right:15px; padding-left:15px;"}
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### sf

{sf} allows users to encode spatial vector data. It simplifies the process of working with spatial vectors in R. This package is often a prerequisite for packages that spatially map lines or points across geographical spaces. 

:::
:::

## General cleaning


::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}
</a href="https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/"> 
![](images/hex/dplyr_hex.png){style="padding-right:15px; padding-left:15px;"}
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}

### dplyr

{dplyr} is a fundamental package of the tidyverse. It allows you to manipulate and filter your data to create summaries, or to restructure your data (e.g. columns and rows) into  preferable positions or format for further analysis. 

:::
:::


::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}
</a href="https://tidyr.tidyverse.org/"> 
![](images/hex/tidyr_hex.png){style="padding-right:15px; padding-left:15px;"}
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### tidyr

Alike dplyr, {tidyr} is a package with reformatting tools that allows you to manipulate your data in such a way that it can be analysed in a preferred manner. If your goal is to have "tidy data": where each variable as a column, each observation within those variables as a row, and each value within a single cell - this package provides whole of data set functions to achieve that. You can also use the `drop_na` function to remove redundant `NA` values from your dataset. 

:::
:::

::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}
</a href="https://stringr.tidyverse.org/">
![](images/hex/stringr_hex.png){style="padding-right:15px; padding-left:15px;"}
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}

### stringr

{stringr} is a package within the tidyverse. It allows you to identify patterns and clean string data (data that involves characters, words or sentences) for things like typos or accidental spaces. Errors like these can impact your ability to merge data together and conduct accurate analyses, therefore, they are important to pick up in the initial phases of data cleaning. 

:::
:::


::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}

</a href="https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/janitor/vignettes/janitor.html">

![](images/hex/janitor_logo.png){style="padding-right:15px; padding-left:38px;"}
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### janitor

{janitor} is a R package to use for pre-cleaning data,
especially when working with large data sets. It can help prepare data
column names into a consistent format in order for combining data sets
or simply the ease of processing of data later on (`clean_names`). For
example, you might want to keep all column names lower case using
underscores instead. You can quickly find any duplicate records
(`get_dupes()`) using and produce counts of various combinations of
data.
:::
:::


::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}
</a href="https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/">

![](images/hex/ggplot2_hex.png){style="padding-right:15px; padding-left:15px;"}
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### ggplot2

{ggplot2} is a tidyverse package that allows users to visualise data in a range of different ways. It also functions with other extension packages, allowing freedom to create a broad range of data visualisations.  
:::
:::

::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}

</a href="https://docs.ropensci.org/taxize/articles/taxize.html">

### taxize

{taxize} allows users the ability to search taxonomic synonyms over many taxonomic data sources using scientific and common names to resolve synonyms in their data.
